LeadPara.Para: Krysten Ritter says playing the superhero in the acclaimed series has boosted her career and she pays attention to what fans say
Sit down with Krysten Ritter and you will see that she is perfectly cast as Jessica Jones - the drywitted, straight-talking private detective who is as direct as Marvel superheroes come.

TailParas.Para: When The Straits Times met the actress in New York late last year to chat about the acclaimed series - which debuted in 2015 and recently launched its second season on Netflix - she seemed just as forthright as her alter ego, albeit more cheerful and animated.

Ritter is a lot more in-your-face than the average celebrity dealing with the press, looking the interviewer in the eye, asking questions of her own and even offering Manhattan sightseeing tips - all in a rapid-fire, expletive-laden patter.
And she is not shy about saying what a big impact Jessica Jones has had on her career or that she pays close attention to what fans and critics say - which many stars are reluctant to admit.
Playing the character has been "100 per cent" life-changing, she reveals.
"When I sign on to a job, you never think about the end result. I just want to work hard and have a show be great and give it everything I've got.
"But the fact that it's big and people watch it - and it's on a platform like Netflix that makes it global - people now know that you're Jessica Jones when you go out of the house.

The fact that it's big and people watch it... People now know that you're Jessica Jones when you go out of the house. That's the most life-changing thing - that people have actually seen it and like it.
KRYSTEN RITTER, who plays the straight-talking private detective Jessica Jones on the acclaimed series
"That's the most life-changing thing - that people have actually seen it and like it."

Equally meaningful has been the show's portrayal of a complex female protagonist and its thoughtful treatment of rape - along with the post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and addiction that can follow.

Viewers continue to parse it for these broader themes and social commentary in its second season, and many hail Jones as a feminist hero - a lively discourse that the 36-year-old actress keeps a close eye on. "I'm very aware of it and very focused on it. And I, as a girl growing up and not ever seeing characters like Jessica Jones, I take that (to heart), because she means a lot to me. She's everything that a woman can be."
She also revels in the fact that Jones does not look or dress like most women Hollywood serve up for mass consumption.
"She's not sexed up. She lives in this grey area - she's androgynous, she's strong, she cries sometimes, she's everything.
"The fact that when the show came out, it started all of these great think pieces and conversations about gender, rape and PTSD, and how well the show tackles those issues, I'm beyond proud of it."

But Ritter - whose breakout role was as the title character in the sitcom Don't Trust The B**** In Apartment 23 (2012 to 2013), where she plays a nightmare roommate - says her day-to-day focus is the character and storylines, which follow Jones as she takes on bad guys and tries to help people through her detective work.
"It's really character first. The social commentary is an added bonus.

"And those issues come because we're so focused on these characters," says the star, who is in a relationship with 39-year-old musician Adam Granduciel, the frontman of indie-rock band The War On Drugs.
The actress is optimistic about the future of an atypical superhero series such as this, even given the complaint that the genre is oversaturated and fans are growing jaded.
"When I got the call saying, 'Oh, Netflix wants to see you for this superhero show', I was, like, 'Oh my god, that's so not me, but I'll go anyway.'
"Then I get the material and I see that this is a dark character study with deep emotional work and she's funny and all these things. So for me, this is a drama with a superhero on the set."

Ritter, who also performs in the indie-rock duo Ex Vivian and last November released a well-reviewed debut novel, the thriller Bonfire, believes more traditional superhero tales such as last year's Wonder Woman movie occupy a different storytelling space from Jessica Jones.

"I just think our worlds are so different. When I watch Wonder Woman, I'm so excited. I was screaming at the screen in the movie theatre - like, when I saw that little girl (playing the young Wonder Woman) in the background doing the fight moves."
She adds: "To me, Jessica Jones never feels like a superhero. She just feels like a woman."
"She just happens to be able to throw people through walls."
• Season 2 of Jessica Jones is available on Netflix.
